name: Asher
comment info:
I notice that there needs to be extensive growth in both wind and solar in the US in order to meet that goal by 2050. I also noticed that there needs to be much more growth in terms of wind than solar power. 
I wonder is if this goal is even realistic. Looking at the growth needed vs the growth that has already happened we need to be moving much faster in order to reach that goal. Perhaps a compromise is in order or maybe even consideration of alternative power sources like nuclear or hydro power for example. Yet another worry is whether or not this solution is cost effective or even particularly environmentally conscious. Solar panels last on average 25-30 years and they contain hazardous waste such as lead and cadmium. Wind turbine blades are generally made out of fiberglass which is not biodegradable. They only last up to 25 years and cannot be recycled. What do we plan on doing with all of this hazardous or non biodegradable waste that will inevitably be created? 
Interestingly Hawaii is not featured in this study. However I believe that Hawaii has committed to a plan to become completely carbon neutral by 2045. This graph does not relate directly to us but it is interesting to note that Hawaii is supposedly at least 5 years ahead of the curve. That being said I must emphasize the “supposedly”, Hawaii is notoriously bad at implementing plans (all my Hawaiian homies know exactly what I’m talking about).
“The wind of change blows strong, but it may need to blow stronger”

name: The Montessori School
comment info:
This week’s WGOITG is so timely - we just had a  conversation Monday about this very topic! We discussed the benefits and disadvantages of fossil fuels, and this graph shows the country looking for better ways to get energy. Fossil fuels are non renewable, but wind and solar energy are renewable. 

We noticed: In the 2050 map: there is more orange in the east than west; the center of the country has mainly wind, with solar on the coasts; there will be wind energy off the coasts. Hawaii and Alaska are not included in either map. 

We wonder: How much fossil fuel will we still use in this net zero scenario? Why won’t there be more solar energy? How will wind energy work on the ocean? What will be the side effects of these changes? Why are we still relying so much on fossil fuels? 

The connection to our community:
In north Louisiana, there are not currently any wind or solar sources, and in 2050, Louisiana is not going to get much more than it has now. Does fewer sites in our state mean we will still be using fossil fuels, or will we get our energy from other states? Why doesn’t the 2050 map show more windfarms off our coast? Oil and gas have a strong presence in our state. We wonder how much influence this will have in the next 30 years. 

Some possible headlines: 
“Green-work makes the Dream-work! How green America will be in the future!”
“Our 50 State Plan for 2050”
“Renewable sources of energy and you: How we can work together to fight climate change!"

name: Ethan
comment info:
I noticed that this is unrealistic. Eliminating so many plants that provide power to people and trying to replace them with solar panels and wind turbines would require more than "a lot more" panels and turbines. Solar panels and wind turbines do not last forever. Solar panels have a lifespan of about 25 to 30 years, and wind turbine have a lifespan of about 20 years. This means that we would have to replace ALL the solar panels and wind turbines at most every 30 years. These things are not cheap to produce, and making solar panels requires a huge increase in global mining mining (https://www.manhattan-institute.org/mines-minerals-and-green-energy-reality-check). So these "renewables" aren't so renewable after all. Plus they don't get the job done. We saw from afar last winter as people were left without power in a blizzard due to unreliable solar and wind energy. California had rolling blackouts due to not having enough energy available for everyone.
I want numbers on this graph. I want to know how much land we are devoting to this unreliable, expensive, dream. On the other hand, it probably won't happen. People will wake up to the reality that this doesn't work, and any republican president, who will like directly replace Biden, seeing as his approval rating is falling fast, won't let this happen. I'm running out of room here, so I won't get too far into the reasons why they want this to happen. I'll leave you with this thought. The climate changes. It happens. it's normal.

name: Karen
comment info: This map chart shows where wind and solar power farms are currently located in the U.S. on one map and the number of those farms that we will need in order to have net-zero emission by 2050 on another.   It looks like we need about ten times the number of wind farms we currently have in the next 29 years if we are to meet the net-zero emissions goal.  The 2050 map also has a lot more wind than solar farms. It shows that we will need to expand wind farms into the ocean areas off the coasts of many northeastern states, as well as a some southern and northwestern states.  This may not be very well-received by the people who live there.  Those places are know for their tourism and they might be worried that the wind farms will be ugly and affect whether people want to come to their beaches. I wonder how the Princeton Net-Zero American study determined where to put the new wind and solar farms.  Right now there is only a small amount of land in Iowa where there are wind farms.  The net-zero map would require about 3/4 of Iowa to be covered in wind farms.  Right now the windmills can be in farm fields and don't reduce the amount of land that can be farmed.  But with so many more windmills would Iowa lose farmland?  This could be a problem for the whole U.S. because we grow a lot of feed corn that is used around the country.  A catchy title for the graph would be "Can America Tolerate a Bigger Solar and Wind Farm Footprint?"

replies.comment info:

name: Dung
comment info:
We need 400% times more of renewable sources to reach net-zero goal by 2050
In general, it appears that wind power is much more needed by 2050 than solar. Specifically in the central areas, there is a huge contrast between the present footprint of wind power and what’s needed in the future. This also means a huge amount of work is expected to reach the goal. Most of needed solar power in the future is more likely to be concentrated in the south along the coastal line.
The contrast between two chosen colours is undesirable because it gives a false impression on the scale(as if we need more wind power due to its stronger colour, whereas statistically it might be false). So I wonder if my observation is actually correct. Besides, I wonder if there is a linear scale in the amount of wind & solar power which should be built every year. For example, we will ever achieve the goal only if we manage to build 500000 energy systems every year? Less is dangerous? Can we downscale the number of solar and wind power and replace it with nuclear power, which is more efficient?
I am not a US citizen, but we all know that how big countries deal and achieve climate goals can set a huge impact on other regions/countries in the world. Some small countries can build up their solutions and try to get prepared on its own. However, climate change is a global issue and if a problem can be solved only a large scale in a big country, it's obviously more applicable to a smaller country than vice-versa.
